page.title: 12LANDSCAPE
page.content: In this part of North East Fife the landscape is composed of smooth sided rounded hills which slope gently down to fertile,undulating river valleys which in this area are known as{"Howes {"}or{"Straths". }The highest point is the Mount Hill at 221 metres and from here the land drops down to a height of around 40 metres in the valley floor. The only stream of any importance is the Ladyburn which flows East to join the main River Eden just outside our area. The main rock type is a type of fine-grain lava stone called basalt or whinstone and in a few places this rock comes to the surface. Everywhere else though the underlying rock is hidden underneath a very deep drift cover of glacially deposited moraine which must be several metres deep in places.
